patches.text: The front-face and back-face symbols on double-faced cards from the Tesla set are identical to the type symbols for artifact and sorcery, respectively. However, unlike the type symbols, these face symbols do have an effect on game play. (See rule 711.1.)

A token may also enter the battlefield from the stack. (See rule 608.3b.) This is an exception to rules 110.5a and 110.5b; the token enters the battlefield under the control of the spell's controller and retains its text and characteristics.

A player who has a card with premonition in their hand may put that card face up into their library. This is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority, but only if they could begin to cast that card by putting it onto the stack.

patches.after: If the player wishes to splice any cards onto the spell (see rule 702.46), they reveal those cards in their hand.
patches.text: If the player wishes to apply any resonance effects to the spell, they announce their intention to do so.

If a delayed triggered ability includes any targets, those targets are chosen as the delayed triggered ability is put onto the stack, not the spell or ability creating the delayed triggered ability.
Example: Gaze of Pain is a sorcery with the text “Until end of turn, whenever a creature you control attacks and isn't blocked, you may choose to have it deal damage equal to its power to a target creature. If you do, it assigns no combat damage this turn.” The targets for multiple instances of the delayed triggered ability may be different creatures, and they don't have to be announced before combat.

If the object that's resolving is a permanent spell that's not represented by a card (i.e. a copy of a permanent spell), the object becomes a token as it enters the battlefield. It is no longer a copy of a spell.

patches.text: A text-changing effect applying to its source only changes the text in the text box where it is defined. Other text boxes, such as those added by copy effects, are not modified. Text-changing effects that change the “full text” of an object are exempt from this rule. See rule 612.5.
If a spell or ability refers to the base power and/or toughness of a creature for a calculation, it uses the value as determined after this layer is applied, but before layers 7c–7e are applied.
Despite similar appearance, an ability preceded by an anchor word is not a mode of a modal ability. It is a separate ability. See rule 614.12b.

text.text: One or more nonland permanents form a straight if they can be ordered in such a way that each but the first has a converted mana cost equal to one plus the converted mana cost of the previous permanent.
subrules: A “straight of N”, where N is a number, is a straight that contains exactly N permanents.
“[A player's] longest straight” is the largest number of permanents in a straight consisting only of permanents controlled by that player.

patches.text: Some continuous effects state that a game action or game state is “against the law” for a player. A player “breaks the law” if they perform that action or if the game state matches that state. This is not to be confused with illegal actions and has no immediate effect on gameplay; however, spells and abilities can identify that the law has been broken.

subrules: “Recharge” means “Create a colorless Canister artifact token with ‘{T}, Sacrifice this artifact: Untap target permanent. Activate this ability only during your turn.’”
“Journey” means “Exile the top card of your library. That card becomes journeyed.”

There is an inherent triggered ability associated with journeying. The full text of this ability is “Whenever a creature deals combat damage to one of its controller's opponents, if its controller owns any journeyed cards, the creature's controller puts a journeyed card they own into their hand.” This ability has no source and is controlled by the controller of the creature which dealt the damage that caused it to trigger. This is an exception to rule 112.8.

Journeyed is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the inherent triggered ability and other spells and abilities can identify. Only cards in exile can be or become journeyed. Once a card becomes journeyed, it stays journeyed until it leaves exile or becomes a new object (see rule 406.7). Journeyed is neither an ability nor part of the card's copiable values.

patches.text: An Aura spell without enchant can target any object or player. An Aura without enchant can enchant any object or player.

Warband is a variant of the soulbond ability. “Warband” means “Whenever this creature attacks, if you control both this creature and another attacking creature and both are unpaired, you may pair this creature with another unpaired attacking creature you control until end of turn”.
A warband ability is a soulbond ability. Any effect that looks for an object with soulbond will find a card with warband.
(For example, a creature can't be paired with another creature using a warband ability and with a third creature using a regular soulbond ability at the same time.)

patches.find: or it or the creature it’s paired with leaves the battlefield\.
patches.replace: it or the creature it's paired with leaves the battlefield; or (for warband) the turn ends.

subrules: Resonance appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities: a static ability that functions while the spell is on the stack and a spell ability which may create a replacement effect. “Resonance [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell” and “If this spell's resonance cost was paid, exile it and, as you put your next instant or sorcery spell on the stack to cast it, put this card into its owner's graveyard. If you do, you may copy this card's text box onto that spell, except it doesn't have resonance, and have it become this card's colors in addition to its other colors.”

The text box added by the copy effect is added below any existing text boxes. If the spell resolves, the instructions of its printed text will be followed first, and then the instructions of any spell abilities in the copied text are followed. If multiple replacement effects add text boxes onto the same spell, the one added by the most recently applied effect is ordered last.

Putting the exiled spell into its owner's graveyard is a replacement effect that replaces the proposal of the next spell (rules 601.2a–d). Whether or not to apply the copy and color-changing effect is a decision made during the step described in rule 601.2b.
Dreamwalk is an evasion ability that modifies the rules for the declare blockers step. (See rule 509, “Declare Blockers Step.”)
A creature with dreamwalk can't be blocked by untapped creatures. Instead, the defending player can choose tapped creatures they control to block an attacking creature with dreamwalk.
Dreamwalk does not allow tapped creatures to block creatures without dreamwalk.
Multiple instances of dreamwalk on the same creature are redundant.

Premonition is a keyword that represents a static ability that functions while the card with premonition is in a player's hand. “Premonition N—[cost]” means “If you could begin to cast this card by putting it onto the stack from your hand and your library has at least N cards in it, you may pay [cost] and put it onto your library beneath the Nth card of your library. This card becomes face up in your library. This action doesn't use the stack.”

Cards that are put into a player's library by the premonition ability are put into the library face up. This is an exception to rule 401.2. Players should keep face up cards in an orientation separate from the orientation of cards in a library that are not face-up or otherwise easily visible to all players.

As a face up card with premonition becomes the top card of a player's library, that player casts it without paying its mana cost if able. If that player can't, they turn the face up card face down instead and it becomes the top card of their library. It is no longer face up.

If a one-shot effect causes a player to reveal (or look at, see rule 701.14d), shuffle, or change the order of a card or cards in a library, at least one of which is face up, each such card is turned face down, and then the cards are revealed, shuffled, or reordered.
If a continuous effect causes a face up card to be revealed, that card is both revealed and is face up. If the card somehow ceases to be revealed, the card remains face up.

If a one-shot effect causes a card to be put into the library “face up beneath the top N cards of [a player's] library,” that player puts that card into their library using the process described above.

Decipher is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the spell with decipher is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the spell with decipher is on the stack. “Decipher [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell” and “When you cast this spell, if a decipher cost was paid for it, copy it X times, where X is the number of instant and sorcery cards in your graveyard. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for any of the copies.”

Worship is an activated ability. “Worship [cost]” means “[Cost], {T}: If this permanent isn't devout, put a +1/+1 counter on this permanent and put a +1/+1 counter on target creature without worship. This permanent becomes devout. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”

Devout is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the worship ability and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become devout. Once a permanent becomes devout, it stays devout until it leaves the battlefield. Devout is neither an ability nor part of the permanent's copiable values.
A creature “worships a creature” when one or more +1/+1 counters are put on the second creature as a result of the first creature's worship ability.
Loaded is a static ability. “Loaded N” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with N charge counters on it.”

Reflex is a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could cast the card it's on. “Reflex [cost]” means “You may cast this card any time you could cast an instant by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost.”

Revolution is an activated ability of some double-faced permanent cards. “Revolution” means “{T}, Tap two untapped creatures you control: Transform all permanents with revolution you control. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”
You “revolt” when you activate a revolution ability. This is not to be confused with the ability word revolt, which has no rules meaning and does not appear in rules text.

Possess is a keyword that represents a triggered ability. “Possess” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, you may have target creature an opponent controls become one of your possessions for as long as both remain on the battlefield.”

A permanent becomes “possessed” by another as the result of a possess ability, and becomes that permanent's “possession”. Abilities may refer to a possession, the permanent another permanent possesses, or whether a permanent is possessed. A player's possessions are all permanents possessed by permanents that player controls.
When the possess ability resolves, if its source is no longer on the battlefield, the targeted object does not become possessed.
A possessed permanent ceases to be possessed if it or the permanent possessing it leaves the battlefield.

Torture is a static ability that functions while the spell with torture is on the stack. “Torture” means “For each generic mana in this spell's total cost, you may put a -1/-1 counter on a creature you control rather than pay that mana.”
A player may not put more than one -1/-1 counter on the same creature this way while casting that spell.
The torture ability isn't an additional or alternative cost and applies only after the total cost of the spell with torture is determined.
Multiple instances of torture on the same spell are redundant.

Focus is a keyword that represents two abilities: a static ability that functions while the spell with focus is on the stack, and a triggered ability that functions while the spell with focus is on the stack. “Focus [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell” and “When you cast this spell, if its focus cost was paid, draw a card.” Paying a spell's focus cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h.

Invocation is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the spell with invocation is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the spell with invocation is on the stack. “Invocation” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap two untapped creatures you control” and “When you cast this spell, if its invocation cost was paid, copy it. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy.” Paying a spell's invocation cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h.
If a spell has multiple instances of invocation, each is paid separately and triggers based on its own payment, not any other instance of invocation.

Resurrect is a keyword that represents three static abilities. “Resurrect [cost]” means “You may cast this spell from your graveyard by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost”, “If this permanent was cast for its resurrect cost, it enters the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it”, and “If this permanent would leave the battlefield and it was cast for its resurrect cost, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else.” Casting a spell using its resurrect ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2f–h.
Desperation is a static ability. “Desperation” means “You may have this creature despair as it attacks. When it does, sacrifice it at the beginning of the next end step.”
Despair is a keyword action with no inherent rules meaning. Only permanents can despair.

Hollow is an activated ability that functions while the card with hollow is in a graveyard. “Hollow [cost]” means “[Cost], Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a tapped token that's a copy of this card, except it's black and it's a Zombie in addition to its other types.”
